Inference: Soil moisture rising during rain detections, weather-based reductions, low water usage, low temperatures, and high humidity indicates ideal natural hydration conditions
Description: Rainfall and cool, humid air create optimal environmental moisture, allowing the system to minimize irrigation while soil moisture increases.

Inference: Soil moisture falling during rain detections, weather-based reductions, high temperatures, and low humidity indicates evaporative loss overpowering rainfall
Description: Environmental dryness prevents rain from meaningfully increasing soil moisture.
short rationale: Rain too weak under heat/dry air; low privacy risk.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during no-rain periods, weather-based reductions, low water usage, low temperatures, and high humidity indicates dew-driven or fog-based moisture gain
Description: Condensation contributes to hydration even without rainfall or irrigation.

Inference: Soil moisture falling during no-rain periods, weather-based increases, rising water usage, high temperatures, and low humidity indicates extreme environmental drying
Description: Hot, dry air accelerates evaporation, requiring aggressive irrigation that still fails to maintain moisture.

Inference: Soil moisture rising sharply when rain detections coincide with weather reductions, low water usage, falling temperatures, and rising humidity indicates heavy rainfall
Description: All environmental signals point to strong storms supplying sufficient hydration.

Inference: Soil moisture stable during fluctuating weather logs, temperature swings, humidity changes, irregular rain detections, and variable water usage indicates strong soil buffering capacity
Description: Soil retains moisture regardless of environmental and irrigation variation.

Inference: Soil moisture falling despite rain detections, increased water usage, weather-based increases, high temperatures, and low humidity indicates severe drought conditions
Description: Both irrigation and rainfall fail to counter evaporative losses.

Inference: Water usage rising while soil moisture falls, weather logs show increases, temperatures rise, humidity falls, and no rain detections occur indicates early drought development
Description: Environmental dryness exceeds system watering capacity.
short rationale: Early drought signal; low privacy impact.

Inference: Water usage dropping while soil moisture rises, weather logs show reductions, temperatures fall, humidity rises, and rain detections occur indicates optimal rainfall replacement
Description: Natural rainfall is effectively maintaining soil moisture.

Inference: Water usage staying high during rain detections, weather-based reductions, stable temperatures, and rising humidity with falling soil moisture indicates irrigation misalignment
Description: The system does not shut off irrigation properly despite rain and moist conditions.

Inference: Water usage stable while soil moisture rises and rain detections occur alongside weather reductions and cool, humid air indicates minor rainfall events with delayed infiltration
Description: Moisture improvements occur gradually as environmental conditions support slow absorption.
short rationale: Minor rain with slow infiltration; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage spikes during no rain, weather-based increases, rising temperatures, falling humidity, and falling soil moisture indicates environmental drying with high irrigation demand
Description: The system increases irrigation to offset moisture loss driven by heat and dry air.

Inference: Water usage falling despite weather-based increases, stable temperatures, rising humidity, no rain detections, and falling soil moisture indicates irrigation delivery failure
Description: The system requests more watering but the actual output does not increase.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during weather-based increases, high water usage, mild temperatures, moderate humidity, and no rain detections indicates efficient irrigation absorption
Description: Irrigation sufficiently hydrates soil under moderate environmental conditions.

Inference: Soil moisture falling during weather-based reductions, low water usage, high temperatures, low humidity, and no rain detections indicates under-watering during heat stress
Description: The system reduces irrigation at a time when environmental demand is high, causing moisture loss.
short rationale: Under-watering in heat due to reductions.

Inference: Soil moisture rising during heat, high humidity, rain detections, weather reductions, and low water usage indicates strong storm rainfall overriding heat effects
Description: Rainfall is substantial enough to counteract evaporative heat stress.
short rationale: Storm rainfall countering heat; low privacy risk.

Inference: Soil moisture falling during cool, humid weather with rising water usage, weather-based increases, and no rain detections indicates deep soil dryness
Description: Internal soil layers require significant hydration regardless of favorable atmospheric conditions.
short rationale: Deep dryness despite favorable weather and watering.

Inference: Soil moisture stable during high temperatures, high humidity, intermittent rain detections, rising water usage, and variable weather logs indicates balanced hydrological conditions
Description: Moisture losses and gains balance out, maintaining stability.

Inference: Sharp soil moisture increase during nighttime rain detections, low temperatures, high humidity, weather reductions, and low water usage indicates optimal nocturnal hydration
Description: Night conditions maximize rainfall infiltration and minimize evaporation.
short rationale: Optimal night hydration; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Sharp soil moisture decline during daytime no-rain periods, high temperatures, low humidity, rising water usage, and weather-based increases indicates diurnal evaporative dominance
Description: Daytime heat drives moisture loss even with high irrigation.

Inference: Soil moisture falling while weather logs reduce irrigation, water usage drops, temperature rises, humidity falls, and no rain detections occur indicates mispredicted rainfall
Description: The system reduces irrigation expecting rain that does not occur.

Inference: Soil moisture rising while weather logs increase irrigation, water usage rises, temperature falls, humidity rises, and no rain detections occur indicates soil responsiveness to irrigation under favorable climate conditions
Description: Cool and moist air enhances irrigation effectiveness.

Inference: Soil moisture rising after rain detections end, while temperatures fall, humidity remains high, water usage stays low, and weather logs reduce irrigation indicates delayed soil infiltration
Description: Rainwater percolates downward after the rainfall event concludes.
short rationale: Delayed infiltration after rain; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Soil moisture falling after rain detections end, with temperatures rising, humidity falling, water usage increasing, and weather logs signaling increases indicates rapid post-rain evaporation
Description: Dry atmospheric conditions quickly deplete moisture following rainfall.

Inference: Water usage rising significantly while weather logs increase irrigation, soil moisture still falls, temperatures are high, humidity low, and no rain occurs indicates irrigation insufficiency
Description: Environmental drying exceeds system irrigation capability.

Inference: Water usage staying very low while soil moisture rises, rain detections occur, temperatures fall, humidity rises, and weather logs reduce irrigation indicates full rainfall dominance
Description: Rain alone is responsible for soil hydration.

Inference: Water usage rising with soil moisture rising, no rain detections, temperatures moderate, humidity stable, and weather logs increasing indicates controlled irrigation dominance
Description: Human or automated irrigation adjustments maintain soil moisture without rainfall.

Inference: Soil moisture remaining extremely stable despite major fluctuations in all four other fields indicates high soil water-holding or deep sensor placement
Description: Soil or sensor conditions prevent superficial environmental variation from affecting moisture readings.
short rationale: High water-holding/sensor depth buffers variation; very low sensitivity.
